document.title: A strengthening of the Nyman-Beurling criterion for the Riemann Hypothesis, 2

section.title: A corollary and a constructive approximating sequence

p.text: provides in turn a new proof, albeit of a stronger theorem, of the Nyman-Beurling criterion which bypasses the deep and complicated Hardy space techniques. One should extend it to the
case, that is, to the condition that
does not vanish in a half-plane
. It should be clear also that we have shown this special equivalence criterion to be true:
The Riemann hypothesis is equivalent to the H-convergence of fϵn as →n∞ for all sufficiently small >ϵ0.
In essence what has been done is to apply a summability method to the old natural approximation. The convergence on special subsequences both of

is also necessary and sufficient, and it is proposed here to look further into this alongside with other summability methods for the natural approximation. Indeed, it is worth noticing that E. Bombieri
indicated to us some advantages of using a Cesàro smoothing of the
, that is, to substitute instead the functions

Math.text: ((sum _ (a = 1)) ^ n)@(((mu * a) / a ^ epsilon) * (1 - a / n) * rho _ a)

p.text: which clearly deserves closer study. Independently of each other M. Balazard and E. Bombieri mentioned to the author that a suitable choice of
would lead to a quantitative estimate of the error of approximation as some inverse power of
. Note that we did not employ the dependence on
. This dependence is obviously connected to the slowness of approximation to
). We owe special thanks to M. Balazard for the statement and proof of the following proposition:
If the Riemann hypothesis is true then there is a constant >c0 such that the distance in H between χ and

Math.text: - ((sum _ (a = 1)) ^ n)@(mu * a * e ^ (- c * (logarithm@(a) / logarithm@(logarithm@(n)))) * rho _ a)

p.text: We shall only sketch the proof of this proposition. Applying the Fourier-Mellin map (
we have from Plancherel’s theorem that

(integral _ (real-part@(z) = 1 / 2))@((absolute-value@(zeta * z * ((sum _ (a = 1)) ^ n)@((mu * a) / a ^ (z + epsilon)) - 1)) ^ 2 * (absolute-value@(d * z) / (absolute-value@(z)) ^ 2))

2 * (integral _ (real-part@(z) = 1 / 2))@((absolute-value@(zeta * z * (((sum _ (a = 1)) ^ n)@((mu * a) / a ^ (z + epsilon)) - 1 / (zeta * (z + epsilon))))) ^ 2 * (absolute-value@(d * z) / (absolute-value@(z)) ^ 2))

as follows. If the distance between

is small enough. In the other
case, one uses an estimate of Burnol
stating that under the Riemann hypothesis

bibitem.bibblock: L. Báez-Duarte, On Beurling’s Real Variable Reformulation of the Riemann Hypothesis, Advances in Mathematics, 101, No. 1 (1993), 10-30.
L. Báez-Duarte, A class of invariant unitary operators, Advances in Mathematics, 144, No. 1 (1999), 1-12.
L. Báez-Duarte, Arithmetical versions of the Nyman-Beurling criterion for the Riemann hypothesis, accepted for publication in IJMMS, IJMMS/1324 (2002).
L. Báez-Duarte, M. Balazard, B. Landreau, and E. Saias, Notes sur la fonction ζ de Riemann, 3, Advances in Mathematics, 149, No. 1 (2000), 130-144.
M. Balazard et E. Saias, Notes sur la fonction ζ de Riemann, 1, Adv. in Maths. 139 (1998), 310-321.
A. Beurling, A closure problem related to the Riemann Zeta-function, Proc. Nat. Acad. Sci. 41 (1955), 312-314.
J. F. Burnol, A lower bound in an approximation problem involving the zeroes of the Riemann zeta function, accepted for publication in Adv. in Math., AIM01/048, 2001.
J. F. Burnol, On an analytic estimate in the theory of the Riemann Zeta function and a theorem of Báez-Duarte, preprint, 18 Feb. 2002, available at arXiv.org as math.NT/0202166.
J. B. Conrey and G. Myerson, On the Balazard-Saias criterion for the Riemann hypothesis, posted in http://arXiv.org/abs/math.NT/002254, Feb. 2000.
M. van Frankenhuysen, Zero-Free Regions for the Riemann Zeta-Function, density of invariant Subspaces of Functions, and the Theory of equal Distribution, preprint, 1997.
B. Landreau, F. Richard, Le critère de Beurling et Nyman pour l’hypothèse de Riemann: aspects numériques, Université de Bordeaux, preprint 2001, submitted to Experimental Mathematics.
J. Lee, Convergence and the Riemann Hypothesis, Comm. Korean Math. Soc. 11, (1996), 57-62.
N. Nikolski, Distance formulae and invariant subspaces, with an application to localization of zeroes of the Riemann ζ-function, Ann. Inst. Fourier (Grenoble) 45 (1995), no. 1, 1-17.
B. Nyman, On some groups and semigroups of translations, Thesis, Uppsala, 1950.
H. Rademacher, Topics in Analytic Number Theory, Die Grundleheren der mathematischen Wissenschaften, Band 169, Springer Verlag, New York, 1973.
E. C. Titchmarsh, The Theory of the Riemann Zeta-Function, Clarendon Press, Oxford, 1951.

V. I. Vasyunin, Sur un système biorthogonal relié a l’hypothèse de Riemann, (in Russian) Algebra i Annaliz 7 (1995), 118-135.Also appeared as: On a biorthogonal system related with the Riemann hypothesis, St. Petersburg Math. J. 7 (1996), 405-419.
